Effective Date.narrative:
Under the Unum Policy 4702860, the coverage commences at varying times depending on employment status and cost-sharing. If the employer fully covers the policy, you become insured from the day you are eligible for coverage. However, if you or your employer make incomplete or false statements during the application process, benefits may be reduced or denied retroactively.

The elimination period is 180 days, and benefits start after this period ends. For physicians and administrative officers, monthly benefits can reach a maximum of $15,000, while for other employees, it caps at $5,000. These amounts may be reduced by deductible sources of income or disability earnings.

The maximum period of payment depends on your age at the onset of disability: if you are under 60, benefits continue until age 65 (minimum of 5 years); if you are exactly 60, benefits last for 60 months. The policy also outlines a provision for recurring disabilities in case of rehire within 12 months.

The certificate section emphasizes the importance of reading and keeping this document safely. It contains key terms and provisions that may require legal interpretation, with Unum's claims paying office available to assist in understanding your benefits. If you have any questions about the terms and provisions, or took prescribed drugs or medicines in the 3 months just prior to your effective date of coverage; and if your disability begins in the first 12 months after your effective date of coverage, it may be considered pre-existing.

In addition, eligibility for rehabilitation services and benefits requires medical ability to engage in a return to work program. Your claim file will be reviewed by one of Unum's rehabilitation professionals to determine if a rehabilitation program might help you return to employment. The final decision on your eligibility for participation in the program. medically able to engage in a return to work program; and -  not receiving social security disability benefits, workers' compensation or unemployment insurance when you change policies.

This policy also provide Unum with all required medical evidence. the prior policy and this policy; and 2.  another policy issued by Unum that provided similar coverage for the same pre-existing condition under its coverage.

Effective Date.content: BENEFITS AT A GLANCE LONG TERM DISABILITY PLAN This long term disability plan provides financial protection for you by paying a portion of your income while you are disabled.  The amount you receive is based on the amount you earned before your disability began.  In some cases, you can receive disability payments even if you work while you are disabled. EMPLOYER'S ORIGINAL PLAN EFFECTIVE DATE: June 1, 2005 POLICY NUMBER: 115056  001 ELIGIBLE GROUP(S): All Employees in active employment in the United States with the Employer MINIMUM HOURS REQUIREMENT: Employees must be working at least 30 hours per week. WAITING PERIOD: For employees in an eligible group on or before June 1, 2005:    First of the month coincident with or next following 90 days of continuous active employment For employees entering an eligible group after June 1, 2005:  First of the month coincident with or next following 90 days of continuous active employment REHIRE: If your employment ends and you are rehired within 12 months, your previous work while in an eligible group will apply toward the waiting period.  All other policy provisions apply. WHO PAYS FOR THE COVERAGE: Your Employer pays the cost of your coverage. ELIMINATION PERIOD: 180 days Benefits begin the day after the elimination period is completed. MONTHLY BENEFIT: Physicians and Administrative Officers 60% of monthly earnings to a maximum benefit of $15,000 per month. Your payment may be reduced by deductible sources of income and disability earnings. Some disabilities may not be covered or may have limited coverage under this plan. All Employees not eligible in another group 60% of monthly earnings to a maximum benefit of $5,000 per month. Your payment may be reduced by deductible sources of income and disability earnings. Some disabilities may not be covered or may have limited coverage under this plan. MAXIMUM PERIOD OF PAYMENT: Age at Disability Maximum Period of Payment Less than age 60 To age 65, but not less than 5 years Age 60 60 months

Effective Date.content: CERTIFICATE SECTION Unum Life Insurance Company of America (referred to as Unum) welcomes you as a client. This is your certificate of coverage as long as you are eligible for coverage and you become insured.  You will want to read it carefully and keep it in a safe place. Unum has written your certificate of coverage in plain English.  However, a few terms and provisions are written as required by insurance law.  If you have any questions about any of the terms and provisions, please consult Unum's claims paying office. Unum will assist you in any way to help you understand your benefits. If the terms and provisions of the certificate of coverage (issued to you) are different from the policy (issued to the policyholder), the policy will govern.  Your coverage may be cancelled or changed in whole or in part under the terms and provisions of the policy. The policy is delivered in and is governed by the laws of the governing jurisdiction and to the extent applicable by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) and any amendments.  When making a benefit determination under the policy, Unum has discretionary authority to determine your eligibility for benefits and to interpret the terms and provisions of the policy. For purposes of effective dates and ending dates under the group policy, all days begin at 12:01 a.m. and end at 12:00 midnight at the Policyholder's address. Unum Life Insurance Company of America 2211 Congress Street Portland, Maine 04122

Effective Date.content: Unum considers any statements you or your Employer make in a signed application for coverage a representation and not a warranty.  If any of the statements you or your Employer make are not complete and/or not true at the time they are made, we can: -  reduce or deny any claim; or -  cancel your coverage from the original effective date. We will use only statements made in a signed application as a basis for doing this. If the Employer gives us information about you that is incorrect, we will: -  use the facts to decide whether you have coverage under the plan and in what amounts; and -  make a fair adjustment of the premium.

Effective Date.content: Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition if, you were: -  in active employment and insured under the plan on its effective date; and -  insured by the prior policy at the time of change. In order to receive a payment you must satisfy the pre-existing condition provision under: 1.  the Unum plan; or 2.  the prior carrier's plan, if benefits would have been paid had that policy remained in force. If you do not satisfy Item 1 or 2 above, Unum will not make any payments. If you satisfy Item 1, we will determine your payments according to the Unum plan provisions. If you only satisfy Item 2, we will administer your claim according to the Unum plan provisions.  However, your payment will be the lesser of: a.  the monthly benefit that would have been payable under the terms of the prior plan if it had remained inforce; or b.  the monthly payment under the Unum plan. Your benefits will end on the earlier of the following dates: 1.  the end of the maximum benefit period under the plan; or 2.  the date benefits would have ended under the prior plan if it had remained in force. HOW CAN UNUM'S REHABILITATION AND RETURN TO WORK ASSISTANCE PROGRAM HELP YOU RETURN TO WORK? Unum has a vocational Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program available to assist you in returning to work.  We will determine whether you are eligible for this program, at our sole discretion.  In order to be eligible for rehabilitation services and benefits, you must be medically able to engage in a return to work program. Your claim file will be reviewed by one of Unum's rehabilitation professionals to determine if a rehabilitation program might help you return to gainful employment. As your file is reviewed, medical and vocational information will be analyzed to determine an appropriate return to work program. We will make the final determination of your eligibility for participation in the program.

All other policy provisions apply. WHO PAYS FOR THE COVERAGE: Your Employer pays the cost of your coverage. Minimum Hours Requirement.narrative:
This Unum Policy 4702860 outlines a Long Term Disability Plan, effective since June 1, 2005, offering financial protection for all active US employees by providing a portion of their income during disability. The amount is determined based on pre-disability earnings, and some disabled individuals may still receive payments while working. The minimum hours requirement is 30 hours per week.

The waiting period varies: those employed before June 1, 2005 must wait 90 days, while new employees face a similar wait after 90 days of continuous active employment. Previous work within the first 12 months of rehire applies towards this waiting period. The employer covers the cost of this coverage, and an elimination period of 180 days is in place before benefits commence.

Monthly benefits are determined by role: Physicians and Administrative Officers receive up to 60% of their monthly earnings (with a cap at $15,000), while other employees are capped at $5,000. Income from other sources or disability earnings may reduce these payments. Coverage may be limited for certain disabilities. The maximum payment period lasts until the policyholder turns 60 (for up to 60 months if already 60).

Waiting Period.narrative: This Unum Policy 4702860.pdf details a Long Term Disability Plan, effective June 1, 2005 (Policy Number: 115056  001), providing financial protection for eligible all U.S. employees of the employer working at least 30 hours per week. The waiting period, crucial to plan eligibility, varies based on employment start date: 90 days of continuous active employment for those employed before June 1, 2005 and after for new hires. Employees may receive disability payments even while working in certain cases. The elimination period is 180 days, benefits begin after completion, and the employer bears coverage costs. Monthly benefits range from 60% of earnings to a maximum of $15,000 or $5,000 depending on eligibility status. Coverage duration depends on age at disability, ranging from less than 60 to age 65 but not less than 5 years for those aged 60. Rehire within 12 months preserves waiting period and pre-existing conditions exclusion. Family and medical leaves of absence may prolong coverage as per employer's policy. This plan does not apply to any divisions, subsidiaries, or affiliated companies. Eligibility for coverage is contingent on the later of the plan effective date or the day after completing the waiting period, with 100% coverage commencement at 12:01 a.m. on that date when the employer bears full costs; partial employer-employee sharing commences when SICKNESS means an illness or disease, and disability must begin while covered under the plan. Survivor eligibility includes spouse (if living) or children under age 25, while Total Covered Payroll refers to the total amount of monthly earnings for which employees are insured under this plan.

Waiting Period.content: We will continue the employee's coverage in accordance with the policyholder's Human Resource policy on family and medical leaves of absence if premium payments continue and the policyholder approved the employee's leave in writing. Coverage will be continued until the end of the later of: 1.  the leave period required by the federal Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and any amendments; or 2.  the leave period required by applicable state law. If the policyholder's Human Resource policy doesn't provide for continuation of an employee's coverage during a family and medical leave of absence, the employee's coverage will be reinstated when he or she returns to active employment. We will not: -  apply a new waiting period; -  apply a new pre-existing conditions exclusion; or -  require evidence of insurability. Elimination Period.content: We encourage you to notify us of your claim as soon as possible, so that a claim decision can be made in a timely manner.  Written notice of a claim should be sent within 30 days after the date your disability begins.  However, you must send Unum written proof of your claim no later than 90 days after your elimination period.  If it is not possible to give proof within 90 days, it must be given no later than 1 year after the time proof is otherwise required except in the absence of legal capacity. The claim form is available from your Employer, or you can request a claim form from us.  If you do not receive the form from Unum within 15 days of your request, send Unum written proof of claim without waiting for the form. You must notify us immediately when you return to work in any capacity. HOW DO YOU FILE A CLAIM? You and your Employer must fill out your own sections of the claim form and then give it to your attending physician.  Your physician should fill out his or her section of the form and send it directly to Unum.

Elimination Period.selected_text: You must be continuously disabled through your  elimination period .  Unum will
Elimination Period.content: You must be continuously disabled through your  elimination period .  Unum will treat your disability as continuous if your disability stops for 30 days or less during the elimination period.  The days that you are not disabled will not count toward your elimination period. Your elimination period is 180 days. You are not required to have a 20% or more loss in your indexed monthly earnings due to the same injury or sickness to be considered disabled during the elimination period. CAN YOU SATISFY YOUR ELIMINATION PERIOD IF YOU ARE WORKING? Yes.  If you are working while you are disabled, the days you are disabled will count toward your elimination period.

Elimination Period.content: You must be continuously disabled through your  elimination period .  Unum will treat your disability as continuous if your disability stops for 30 days or less during the elimination period.  The days that you are not disabled will not count toward your elimination period. Your elimination period is 180 days. You are not required to have a 20% or more loss in your indexed monthly earnings due to the same injury or sickness to be considered disabled during the elimination period. CAN YOU SATISFY YOUR ELIMINATION PERIOD IF YOU ARE WORKING? Yes.  If you are working while you are disabled, the days you are disabled will count toward your elimination period.

This is the amount Unum will pay you each month. Unum may require you to send proof of your monthly disability earnings at least quarterly. As part of your proof of disability earnings, we can require that you send us appropriate financial records which we believe are necessary to substantiate your income. After the elimination period, if you are disabled for less than 1 month, we will send you 1/30 of your payment for each day of disability. HOW CAN WE PROTECT YOU IF YOUR DISABILITY EARNINGS FLUCTUATE? If your disability earnings routinely fluctuate widely from month to month, Unum may average your disability earnings over the most recent 3 months to determine if your claim should continue. If Unum averages your disability earnings, we will not terminate your claim unless the average of your disability earnings from the last 3 months exceeds 80% of indexed monthly earnings. We will not pay you for any month during which disability earnings exceed 80% of indexed monthly earnings.

Elimination Period.selected_text: ELIMINATION PERIOD  means a period of continuous disability which must be satisfied
Elimination Period.content: GLOSSARY ACTIVE EMPLOYMENT  means you are working for your Employer for earnings that are paid regularly and that you are performing the material and substantial duties of your regular occupation.  You must be working at least the minimum number of hours as described under Eligible Group(s) in each plan. Your work site must be: -  your Employer's usual place of business; -  an alternative work site at the direction of your Employer, including your home; or -  a location to which your job requires you to travel. Normal vacation is considered active employment. Temporary and seasonal workers are excluded from coverage. DEDUCTIBLE SOURCES OF INCOME  means income from deductible sources listed in the plan which you receive or are entitled to receive while you are disabled.  This income will be subtracted from your gross disability payment. DEPENDENT  means: -  your child(ren) under the age of 15; and -  your child(ren) age 15 or over or a family member who requires personal care assistance. DISABILITY EARNINGS  means the earnings which you receive while you are disabled and working, plus the earnings you could receive if you were working to your  maximum capacity . ELIMINATION PERIOD  means a period of continuous disability which must be satisfied before you are eligible to receive benefits from Unum. EMPLOYEE  means a person who is in active employment in the United States with the Employer. EMPLOYER  means the Policyholder, and includes any division, subsidiary or affiliated company named in the policy. EVIDENCE OF INSURABILITY  means a statement of your medical history which Unum will use to determine if you are approved for coverage.  Evidence of insurability will be at Unum's expense. All Employees not eligible in another group GAINFUL OCCUPATION  means an occupation that is or can be expected to provide you with an income within 12 months of your return to work, that exceeds: 80% of your indexed monthly earnings, if you are working; or 60% of your indexed monthly earnings, if you are not working. GRACE PERIOD  means the period of time following the premium due date during which premium payment may be made.

Maximum Benefit.selected_text: 60% of monthly earnings to a maximum benefit of $15,000 per month.
Maximum Benefit.content: BENEFITS AT A GLANCE LONG TERM DISABILITY PLAN This long term disability plan provides financial protection for you by paying a portion of your income while you are disabled.  The amount you receive is based on the amount you earned before your disability began.  In some cases, you can receive disability payments even if you work while you are disabled. EMPLOYER'S ORIGINAL PLAN EFFECTIVE DATE: June 1, 2005 POLICY NUMBER: 115056  001 ELIGIBLE GROUP(S): All Employees in active employment in the United States with the Employer MINIMUM HOURS REQUIREMENT: Employees must be working at least 30 hours per week. WAITING PERIOD: For employees in an eligible group on or before June 1, 2005:    First of the month coincident with or next following 90 days of continuous active employment For employees entering an eligible group after June 1, 2005:  First of the month coincident with or next following 90 days of continuous active employment REHIRE: If your employment ends and you are rehired within 12 months, your previous work while in an eligible group will apply toward the waiting period.  All other policy provisions apply. WHO PAYS FOR THE COVERAGE: Your Employer pays the cost of your coverage. ELIMINATION PERIOD: 180 days Benefits begin the day after the elimination period is completed. MONTHLY BENEFIT: Physicians and Administrative Officers 60% of monthly earnings to a maximum benefit of $15,000 per month. Your payment may be reduced by deductible sources of income and disability earnings. Some disabilities may not be covered or may have limited coverage under this plan. All Employees not eligible in another group 60% of monthly earnings to a maximum benefit of $5,000 per month. Your payment may be reduced by deductible sources of income and disability earnings. Some disabilities may not be covered or may have limited coverage under this plan. MAXIMUM PERIOD OF PAYMENT: Age at Disability Maximum Period of Payment Less than age 60 To age 65, but not less than 5 years Age 60 60 months
Maximum Benefit.narrative:
Here's Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance Program coordinators to determine your eligibility for this program can help you return to work.

   The program offers vocational services that may include job placement assistance, education and training, and job search strategies. If eligible, a Unum will assign a Rehabilitator who will work with you to develop a rehabilitation plan tailored to your specific needs, up to a maximum monthly benefit. This additional benefit can reach $1,00 per month.

   Unum's regular maximum period of payment or reduce your disability payment. The additional benefit will continue for 3 months after you have returned to work, if you are still in effect.

   Unum also provide dependent care expenses up to $350 date your disability ends if we determine you are no longer disabled and unable to find employment. These payments can reach up to a maximum of $1,000 - you are not able to find employment. The dependent care assistance will cover certain dependent care expenses limited to the following amounts: per month, per dependent Dependent Care Expense Benefit Amount: $350, $1,00 Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance Program will end when one of the following occurs:

   1. You reach Maximum Capacity in your regular occupation that is reasonably available.
   2. You reach Maximum Capacity in any occupation that is reasonably available for which you are reasonably fitted by education, training or experience after 24 months of disability.
   3. The maximum period of payment under the plan has ended.
   4. Your employment has resumed and you have been earning at least 80% of your indexed monthly earnings for a consecutive 6-month period.

The Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance Program may help eligible employees return to work by providing vocational, educational, training, and job search services. This program offers an additional disability benefit up to $1,000 per month for 3 months after you have returned to work. Dependent care expenses may also be covered during this time if necessary.

Maximum Benefit.selected_text: The lifetime cumulative maximum benefit period for all disabilities due to  mental
Maximum Benefit.content: The lifetime cumulative maximum benefit period for all disabilities due to  mental illness  and disabilities based primarily on  self-reported symptoms  is 24 months. Only 24 months of benefits will be paid for any combination of such disabilities even if the disabilities: -  are not continuous; and/or -  are not related. Unum will continue to send you payments beyond the 24 month period if you meet one or both of these conditions: 1.  If you are confined to a  hospital or institution  at the end of the 24 month period, Unum will continue to send you payments during your confinement. If you are still disabled when you are discharged, Unum will send you payments for a recovery period of up to 90 days. If you become reconfined at any time during the recovery period and remain confined for at least 14 days in a row, Unum will send payments during that additional confinement and for one additional recovery period up to 90 more days. 2.  In addition to Item 1, if, after the 24 month period for which you have received payments, you continue to be disabled and subsequently become confined to a hospital or institution for at least 14 days in a row, Unum will send payments during the length of the reconfinement. Unum will not pay beyond the limited pay period as indicated above, or the maximum period of payment, whichever occurs first. Unum will not apply the mental illness limitation to dementia if it is a result of: -  stroke; -  trauma; -  viral infection; -  Alzheimer's disease; or -  other conditions not listed which are not usually treated by a mental health provider or other qualified provider using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or other similar methods of treatment.

Maximum Benefit.content: Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition if, you were: -  in active employment and insured under the plan on its effective date; and -  insured by the prior policy at the time of change. In order to receive a payment you must satisfy the pre-existing condition provision under: 1.  the Unum plan; or 2.  the prior carrier's plan, if benefits would have been paid had that policy remained in force. If you do not satisfy Item 1 or 2 above, Unum will not make any payments. If you satisfy Item 1, we will determine your payments according to the Unum plan provisions. If you only satisfy Item 2, we will administer your claim according to the Unum plan provisions.  However, your payment will be the lesser of: a.  the monthly benefit that would have been payable under the terms of the prior plan if it had remained inforce; or b.  the monthly payment under the Unum plan. Your benefits will end on the earlier of the following dates: 1.  the end of the maximum benefit period under the plan; or 2.  the date benefits would have ended under the prior plan if it had remained in force. HOW CAN UNUM'S REHABILITATION AND RETURN TO WORK ASSISTANCE PROGRAM HELP YOU RETURN TO WORK? Unum has a vocational Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program available to assist you in returning to work.  We will determine whether you are eligible for this program, at our sole discretion.  In order to be eligible for rehabilitation services and benefits, you must be medically able to engage in a return to work program. Your claim file will be reviewed by one of Unum's rehabilitation professionals to determine if a rehabilitation program might help you return to gainful employment. As your file is reviewed, medical and vocational information will be analyzed to determine an appropriate return to work program. We will make the final determination of your eligibility for participation in the program.

Maximum Benefit.content: Physicians and Administrative Officers MAXIMUM CAPACITY  means, based on your restrictions and limitations, the greatest extent of work you are able to do in your regular occupation, that is reasonably available. All Employees not eligible in another group MAXIMUM CAPACITY  means, based on your restrictions and limitations: -  during the first 24 months of disability, the greatest extent of work you are able to do in your regular occupation, that is reasonably available. -  beyond 24 months of disability, the greatest extent of work you are able to do in any occupation, that is reasonably available, for which you are reasonably fitted by education, training or experience. MAXIMUM PERIOD OF PAYMENT  means the longest period of time Unum will make payments to you for any one period of disability. MENTAL ILLNESS  means a psychiatric or psychological condition classified in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Health Disorders (DSM), published by the American Psychiatric Association, most current as of the start of a disability.  Such disorders include, but are not limited to, psychotic, emotional or behavioral disorders, or disorders relatable to stress.  If the DSM is discontinued or replaced, these disorders will be those classified in the diagnostic manual then used by the American Psychiatric Association as of the start of a disability. MONTHLY BENEFIT  means the total benefit amount for which an employee is insured under this plan subject to the maximum benefit. MONTHLY EARNINGS  means your gross monthly income from your Employer as defined in the plan. MONTHLY PAYMENT  means your payment after any deductible sources of income have been subtracted from your gross disability payment. PART-TIME BASIS  means the ability to work and earn between 20% and 80% of your indexed monthly earnings. PAYABLE CLAIM  means a claim for which Unum is liable under the terms of the policy. PHYSICIAN  means: -  a person performing tasks that are within the limits of his or her medical license; and -  a person who is licensed to practice medicine and prescribe and administer drugs or to perform surgery; or -  a person with a doctoral degree in Psychology (Ph.D. or Psy.D.) whose primary practice is treating patients; or -  a person who is a legally qualified medical practitioner according to the laws and regulations of the governing jurisdiction. Unum will not recognize you, or your spouse, children, parents or siblings as a physician for a claim that you send to us. PLAN  means a line of coverage under the policy.

Dependent Care Expense Benefit.narrative:
1. The Dependent Care Expense Benefit is available to policyholders who are disabled and incurring expenses to provide care for a child under the age of 15 or a family member who needs personal care assistance, as stated in Unum Policy 4702860.pdf on pages [5, 26, 27].

   2. The benefit amount is $350 per month, per dependent, and does not exceed $1,000 per month for all dependent care expenses combined. To receive this benefit, the policyholder must provide satisfactory proof of the incurred expenses.

   3. The Dependent Care Expense Benefits will end on the earlier of:
       a. The date the policyholder is no longer incurring expenses for their dependent;
       b. The date the policyholder is no longer participating in Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program; or
       c. Any other date payments would stop in accordance with this plan.

   4. The payment of the Dependent Care Expense Benefit begins immediately after the policyholder starts Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program.

   5. Similarly, if a policyholder starts incurring expenses to provide care for a child age 15 or older or a family member who needs personal care assistance, they are also eligible for the Dependent Care Expense Benefit under the same conditions.

Continuity of Coverage.narrative: This Unum policy, as detailed in document 4702860.pdf, offers continued coverage to individuals aged 61-69 for varying periods (up to 12 months past age 69), with no premium payments required while receiving benefits. Key benefits include a Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance benefit of up to 10% of gross disability payment or $1,000 monthly, plus three additional months' pay post-disability cessation if participating in the program and unable to find employment. Dependent care expenses are covered under the Dependent Care Expense Benefit, limited to $350 per dependent, $1,000 monthly combined maximum, with the total benefit cap not exceeding 110% of monthly earnings (for those in rehab programs). A survivor benefit is payable as a lump sum equivalent to three months of gross disability payment if the policyholder has been disabled for 180 consecutive days and is receiving payments. This benefit can be accessed prior to death if terminally ill, but doing so waives the post-death survivor benefit. The Continuity of Coverage feature ensures benefits continue when an employer switches to Unum.

Continuity of Coverage.selected_text: CHANGES INSURANCE CARRIERS TO UNUM? (Continuity of Coverage)
Continuity of Coverage.content: When Unum receives proof that you have died, we will pay your  eligible survivor  a lump sum benefit equal to 3 months of your gross disability payment if, on the date of your death: -  your disability had continued for 180 or more consecutive days; and -  you were receiving or were entitled to receive payments under the plan. If you have no eligible survivors, payment will be made to your estate, unless there is none.  In this case, no payment will be made. However, we will first apply the survivor benefit to any overpayment which may exist on your claim. You may receive your 3 month survivor benefit prior to your death if you have been diagnosed as terminally ill. We will pay you a lump sum amount equal to 3 months of your gross disability payment if: -  you have been diagnosed with a terminal illness or condition; -  your life expectancy has been reduced to less than 12 months; and -  you are receiving monthly payments. Your right to exercise this option and receive payment is subject to the following: -  you must make this election in writing to Unum; and -  your physician must certify in writing that you have a terminal illness or condition and your life expectancy has been reduced to less than 12 months. This benefit is available to you on a voluntary basis and will only be payable once. If you elect to receive this benefit prior to your death, no 3 month survivor benefit will be payable upon your death. WHAT IF YOU ARE NOT IN ACTIVE EMPLOYMENT WHEN YOUR EMPLOYER CHANGES INSURANCE CARRIERS TO UNUM? (Continuity of Coverage)
Continuity of Coverage.narrative: This Unum policy, as detailed in document 4702860.pdf, offers continued coverage to individuals aged 61-69 for varying periods (up to 12 months past age 69), with no premium payments required while receiving benefits. Key benefits include a Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance benefit of up to 10% of gross disability payment or $1,000 monthly, plus three additional months' pay post-disability cessation if participating in the program and unable to find employment. Dependent care expenses are covered under the Dependent Care Expense Benefit, limited to $350 per dependent, $1,000 monthly combined maximum, with the total benefit cap not exceeding 110% of monthly earnings (for those in rehab programs). A survivor benefit is payable as a lump sum equivalent to three months of gross disability payment if the policyholder has been disabled for 180 consecutive days and is receiving payments. This benefit can be accessed prior to death if terminally ill, but doing so waives the post-death survivor benefit. The Continuity of Coverage feature ensures benefits continue when an employer switches to Unum.

REHABILITATION AND RETURN TO WORK ASSISTANCE BENEFIT: 10% of your gross disability payment to a maximum benefit of $1,000 per month. In addition, we will make monthly payments to you for 3 months following the date your disability ends if we determine you are no longer disabled while: -  you are participating in the Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program; and -  you are not able to find employment. DEPENDENT CARE EXPENSE BENEFIT: While you are participating in Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program, you may receive payments to cover certain dependent care expenses limited to the following amounts: Dependent Care Expense Benefit Amount:  $350 per month, per dependent Dependent Care Expense Maximum Benefit Amount:  $1,000 per month for all eligible dependent care expenses combined TOTAL BENEFIT CAP: The total benefit payable to you on a monthly basis (including all benefits provided under this plan) will not exceed 100% of your monthly earnings.  However, if you are participating in Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program, the total benefit payable to you on a monthly basis (including all benefits provided under this plan) will not exceed 110% of your monthly earnings. OTHER FEATURES: Continuity of Coverage Minimum Benefit Pre-Existing: 3/12 Survivor Benefit Work Life Assistance Program The above items are only highlights of this plan.  For a full description of your coverage, continue reading your certificate of coverage section.
Minimum Benefit.narrative: This Unum Policy 4702860.pdf outlines key features of disability coverage. Age-specific benefits expire between 48 months (at age 61) and 12 months (for those aged 69+), with no premium payments required during benefit receipt. A Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance Benefit offers 10% of gross disability payment up to $1,000 per month and additional payments for 3 months post-disability cessation if one is participating in the program and unable to find work. Dependent Care Expense Benefit allows coverage for certain expenses limited to $350 per dependent per month and a total of $1,000 combined, with the total monthly benefit (including all plan benefits) not exceeding 100% of earnings but up to 110% if in rehabilitation. The Total Benefit Cap does not apply if one is participating in Unum's Rehabilitation program. Other features include Continuity of Coverage, Minimum Benefit for pre-existing conditions (3/12), Survivor Benefit, Work Life Assistance Program, and various exclusions such as tax sheltered annuities, stock ownership plans, pension plans, credit disability insurance, franchise disability income plans, retirement plans from another Employer, individual retirement accounts, individual disability income plans, no fault motor vehicle plans, salary continuation or accumulated sick leave plans. If subtracting deductible sources of income results in a zero benefit, the Minimum Benefit applies.

Survivor Benefit.narrative:
This Unum Policy 4702860.pdf outlines various benefits under a disability plan, including survivor benefits, rehabilitation assistance, and dependent care expenses. The length of monthly payments for disability varies based on age: ages 61-69 receive up to 48 months, while ages 69 and over receive 12 months. A Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance benefit provides 10% of the gross disability payment, up to $1,000 per month, with additional payments for 3 months following disability end under specific conditions. Dependent care expenses are covered up to $350 per dependent, $1,000 monthly in total, as part of the Rehabilitation program. The total payout cannot exceed the monthly disability amount.

The survivor benefit is a lump sum of 3 months' gross disability payment if the policyholder has been disabled for more than 180 days and meets other eligibility requirements. This benefit can be claimed early if the policyholder has a terminal illness with less than 12 months life expectancy.

The policy offers Continuity of Coverage, ensuring benefits remain if the policyholder changes employers and their new employer switches to Unum as the insurance carrier. The survivor benefit conditions apply under this circumstance as well.

Survivor Benefit.content: When Unum receives proof that you have died, we will pay your  eligible survivor  a lump sum benefit equal to 3 months of your gross disability payment if, on the date of your death: -  your disability had continued for 180 or more consecutive days; and -  you were receiving or were entitled to receive payments under the plan. If you have no eligible survivors, payment will be made to your estate, unless there is none.  In this case, no payment will be made. However, we will first apply the survivor benefit to any overpayment which may exist on your claim. You may receive your 3 month survivor benefit prior to your death if you have been diagnosed as terminally ill. We will pay you a lump sum amount equal to 3 months of your gross disability payment if: -  you have been diagnosed with a terminal illness or condition; -  your life expectancy has been reduced to less than 12 months; and -  you are receiving monthly payments. Your right to exercise this option and receive payment is subject to the following: -  you must make this election in writing to Unum; and -  your physician must certify in writing that you have a terminal illness or condition and your life expectancy has been reduced to less than 12 months. This benefit is available to you on a voluntary basis and will only be payable once. If you elect to receive this benefit prior to your death, no 3 month survivor benefit will be payable upon your death. Work Life Assistance Program.narrative: This Unum Policy 4702860 outlines key benefits for individuals aged 61 to 69 and over, providing no-premium coverage during disability payments. The Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program offers a 10% disability payment (up to $1,000/month) and additional monthly payments for 3 months post-disability if participating in the program and unable to find employment. Dependent care expenses are covered up to $350 per dependent or $1,000 combined per month during participation in the Rehabilitation program, with a total monthly benefit not exceeding 100% of your earnings (110% if participating in the Rehab program). The Total Benefit Cap ensures no more than 100% or 110% of monthly earnings are paid. Additional features include Continuity of Coverage, Minimum Benefit Pre-Existing, and a Survivor Benefit. The Work Life Assistance Program offers help with daily living issues, accessible through a toll-free number or online. Unum can aid employers in identifying worksite modifications to facilitate continued employment or return to work.

Work Life Assistance Program.selected_text: IS THERE A WORK LIFE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM AVAILABLE WITH THE PLAN?
Work Life Assistance Program.content: OTHER SERVICES These services are also available from us as part of your Unum Long Term Disability plan. IS THERE A WORK LIFE ASSISTANCE PROGRAM AVAILABLE WITH THE PLAN? We do provide you and your dependents access to a work life assistance program designed to assist you with problems of daily living. You can call and request assistance for virtually any personal or professional issue, from helping find a day care or transportation for an elderly parent, to researching possible colleges for a child, to helping to deal with the stress of the workplace.  This work life program is available for everyday issues as well as crisis support. This service is also available to your Employer. This program can be accessed by a 1-800 telephone number available 24 hours a day, 7 days a week or online through a website. Information about this program can be obtained through your plan administrator.

Waiver of Premium.content: LONG TERM DISABILITY The initial premium for each  plan  is based on the initial rate(s) shown in the Rate Information Amendment(s). WAIVER OF PREMIUM Unum does not require premium payments for an insured while he or she is receiving Long Term Disability payments under this plan. INITIAL RATE GUARANTEE AND RATE CHANGES Refer to the Rate Information Amendment(s). WHEN IS PREMIUM DUE FOR THIS POLICY? Premium Due Dates:  Premium due dates are based on the Premium Due Dates shown in the Rate Information Amendment(s). The  Policyholder  must send all premiums to Unum on or before their respective due date.  The premium must be paid in United States dollars.
Waiver of Premium.narrative: According to Unum Policy 4702860.pdf, the initial premium for the Long Term Disability plan is determined by rates specified in Rate Information Amendments. Notably, Unum waives premium payments while an insured individual receives Long Term Disability benefits under this plan. Regarding rate changes and details, refer to the provided Rate Information Amendments. Premium due dates are based on those shown in the same amendments. The policyholder is expected to send all premiums, payable in US dollars, to Unum before their respective due date.

Pre-existing Condition.content: We will continue the employee's coverage in accordance with the policyholder's Human Resource policy on family and medical leaves of absence if premium payments continue and the policyholder approved the employee's leave in writing. Coverage will be continued until the end of the later of: 1.  the leave period required by the federal Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 and any amendments; or 2.  the leave period required by applicable state law. If the policyholder's Human Resource policy doesn't provide for continuation of an employee's coverage during a family and medical leave of absence, the employee's coverage will be reinstated when he or she returns to active employment. We will not: -  apply a new waiting period; -  apply a new pre-existing conditions exclusion; or -  require evidence of insurability. DIVISIONS, SUBSIDIARIES OR AFFILIATED COMPANIES INCLUDE: NAME/LOCATION (CITY AND STATE) None
Pre-existing Condition.narrative: This document, specifically Unum Policy 4702860.pdf, outlines various aspects of the policy on pages 10, 23, 25, and 33. The policy addresses self-reported symptoms such as headaches, pain, fatigue, and dizziness (among others), which are subjective manifestations not verified through standard medical tests or examinations. Salary continuation or accumulated sick leave refers to payments made by an employer to a disabled individual, as part of an established plan for all covered employees, that is not compensation for work performed post-disability. The policy also mentions Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program available to eligible individuals, who must be medically capable of participating in a return-to-work program might help them regain employment. Eligibility is determined by Unum at their sole discretion. To receive payments from the policy if you satisfy provision under either the Unum or prior carrier's plan, with your eligibility for participation program. Your benefits will end on the earlier of the maximum benefit period or date benefits would have remained in force. The rehabilitation professional services and benefits require medical condition that existed prior to the effective date of the policy, or prescription medication from any provider within a specified lookback period before the policy's effective date or during the policy's Lookback Period section.

Pre-existing Condition.content: Your plan does not cover any disabilities caused by, contributed to by, or resulting from your: -  intentionally self-inflicted injuries. -  active participation in a riot. -  loss of a professional license, occupational license or certification. -  commission of a crime for which you have been convicted. -  pre-existing condition. Your plan will not cover a disability due to war, declared or undeclared, or any act of war. Unum will not pay a benefit for any period of disability during which you are incarcerated. WHAT IS A PRE-EXISTING CONDITION?

Pre-existing Condition.content: WHAT IF YOU HAVE A DISABILITY DUE TO A PRE-EXISTING CONDITION WHEN YOUR EMPLOYER CHANGES INSURANCE CARRIERS TO UNUM? (Continuity of Coverage) Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition if,
Pre-existing Condition.narrative: This document, specifically Unum Policy 4702860.pdf, outlines various aspects of the policy on pages 10, 23, 25, and 33. The policy addresses self-reported symptoms such as headaches, pain, fatigue, and dizziness (among others), which are subjective manifestations not verified through standard medical tests or examinations. Salary continuation or accumulated sick leave refers to payments made by an employer to a disabled individual, as part of an established plan for all covered employees, that is not compensation for work performed post-disability. The policy also mentions Unum's Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program available to eligible individuals, who must be medically capable of participating in a return-to-work program might help them regain employment. Eligibility is determined by Unum at their sole discretion. To receive payments from the policy if you satisfy provision under either the Unum or prior carrier's plan, with your eligibility for participation program. Your benefits will end on the earlier of the maximum benefit period or date benefits would have remained in force. The rehabilitation professional services and benefits require medical condition that existed prior to the effective date of the policy, or prescription medication from any provider within a specified lookback period before the policy's effective date or during the policy's Lookback Period section.

Pre-existing Condition.selected_text: Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition if,
Pre-existing Condition.content: Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition if, you were: -  in active employment and insured under the plan on its effective date; and -  insured by the prior policy at the time of change. In order to receive a payment you must satisfy the pre-existing condition provision under: 1.  the Unum plan; or 2.  the prior carrier's plan, if benefits would have been paid had that policy remained in force. If you do not satisfy Item 1 or 2 above, Unum will not make any payments. If you satisfy Item 1, we will determine your payments according to the Unum plan provisions. If you only satisfy Item 2, we will administer your claim according to the Unum plan provisions.  However, your payment will be the lesser of: a.  the monthly benefit that would have been payable under the terms of the prior plan if it had remained inforce; or b.  the monthly payment under the Unum plan. Your benefits will end on the earlier of the following dates: 1.  the end of the maximum benefit period under the plan; or 2.  the date benefits would have ended under the prior plan if it had remained in force. HOW CAN UNUM'S REHABILITATION AND RETURN TO WORK ASSISTANCE PROGRAM HELP YOU RETURN TO WORK? Unum has a vocational Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program available to assist you in returning to work.  We will determine whether you are eligible for this program, at our sole discretion.  In order to be eligible for rehabilitation services and benefits, you must be medically able to engage in a return to work program. Your claim file will be reviewed by one of Unum's rehabilitation professionals to determine if a rehabilitation program might help you return to gainful employment. As your file is reviewed, medical and vocational information will be analyzed to determine an appropriate return to work program. We will make the final determination of your eligibility for participation in the program.

Pre-existing Condition.selected_text: PRE-EXISTING CONDITION  means a condition for which you received medical
Pre-existing Condition.content: POLICYHOLDER  means the Employer to whom the policy is issued. PRE-EXISTING CONDITION  means a condition for which you received medical treatment, consultation, care or services including diagnostic measures, or took prescribed drugs or medicines for your condition during the given period of time as stated in the plan. RECURRENT DISABILITY  means a disability which is: -  caused by a worsening in your condition; and -  due to the same cause(s) as your prior disability for which Unum made a Long Term Disability payment. REGULAR CARE  means: -  you personally visit a physician as frequently as is medically required, according to generally accepted medical standards, to effectively manage and treat your disabling condition(s); and -  you are receiving the most appropriate treatment and care which conforms with generally accepted medical standards, for your disabling condition(s) by a physician whose specialty or experience is the most appropriate for your disabling condition(s), according to generally accepted medical standards. REGULAR OCCUPATION  means the occupation you are routinely performing when your disability begins.  Unum will look at your occupation as it is normally performed in the national economy, instead of how the work tasks are performed for a specific employer or at a specific location. For physicians, "regular occupation" means your specialty in the practice of medicine which you are routinely performing when your disability begins.  Unum will look at your occupation as it is normally performed in the national economy, instead of how the work tasks are performed for a specific employer or at a specific location. RETIREMENT PLAN  means a defined contribution plan or defined benefit plan.  These are plans which provide retirement benefits to employees and are not funded entirely by employee contributions. Retirement Plan includes but is not limited to any plan which is part of any federal, state, county, municipal or association retirement system. SALARY CONTINUATION OR ACCUMULATED SICK LEAVE  means continued payments to you by your Employer of all or part of your monthly earnings, after you become disabled as defined by the Policy.  This continued payment must be part of an established plan maintained by your Employer for the benefit of all employees covered under the Policy.  Salary continuation or accumulated sick leave does not include compensation paid to you by your Employer for work you actually perform after your disability begins.  Such compensation is considered disability earnings, and would be taken into account in calculating your monthly payment. SELF-REPORTED SYMPTOMS  means the manifestations of your condition which you tell your physician, that are not verifiable using tests, procedures or clinical examinations standardly accepted in the practice of medicine. Examples of self-reported symptoms include, but are not limited to headaches, pain, fatigue, stiffness, soreness, ringing in ears, dizziness, numbness and loss of energy.

Contribution.selected_text: -  the last day of the period for which you made any required contributions; or
Contribution.content: Your coverage under the policy or a plan ends on the earliest of: -  the date the policy or a plan is cancelled; -  the date you no longer are in an eligible group; -  the date your eligible group is no longer covered; -  the last day of the period for which you made any required contributions; or -  the last day you are in active employment except as provided under the covered layoff or leave of absence provision. Unum will provide coverage for a payable claim which occurs while you are covered under the policy or plan. WHAT ARE THE TIME LIMITS FOR LEGAL PROCEEDINGS? You can start legal action regarding your claim 60 days after proof of claim has been given and up to 3 years from the time proof of claim is required, unless otherwise provided under federal law.

Contribution.selected_text: deductions made for pre-tax contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan,
Contribution.content: "Monthly Earnings" means your average gross monthly income as figured: a.  from the income box on your W-2 form which reflects wages, tips and other compensation received from your Employer for the calendar year just prior to your date of disability; or b.  for the period of your employment with your Employer if you did not receive a W- 2 form prior to your date of disability. Average gross monthly income is your total income before taxes.  It is prior to any deductions made for pre-tax contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan, Section 125 plan, or flexible spending account.  It does not include income received from car, housing or moving allowances, Employer contributions to a qualified deferred compensation plan, or income received from sources other than your Employer. WHAT WILL WE USE FOR MONTHLY EARNINGS IF YOU BECOME DISABLED DURING A COVERED LAYOFF OR LEAVE OF ABSENCE? If you become disabled while you are on a covered layoff or leave of absence, we will use your monthly earnings from your Employer in effect just prior to the date your absence begins.

Contribution.selected_text: contribution to the retirement plan.  Disability benefits which reduce the
Contribution.content: -  any similar plan or act. 4. The amount that you receive as retirement payments or the amount your spouse and children receive as retirement payments because you are receiving retirement payments under: -  the United States Social Security Act. -  the Canada Pension Plan. -  the Quebec Pension Plan. -  any similar plan or act. 5. The amount that you: -  receive as disability payments under your Employer's  retirement plan . -  voluntarily elect to receive as retirement payments under your Employer's retirement plan. -  receive as retirement payments when you reach the later of age 62 or normal retirement age, as defined in your Employer's retirement plan. Disability payments under a retirement plan will be those benefits which are paid due to disability and do not reduce the retirement benefit which would have been paid if the disability had not occurred. Retirement payments will be those benefits which are based on your Employer's contribution to the retirement plan.  Disability benefits which reduce the retirement benefit under the plan will also be considered as a retirement benefit. Regardless of how the retirement funds from the retirement plan are distributed, Unum will consider your and your Employer's contributions to be distributed simultaneously throughout your lifetime. Amounts received do not include amounts rolled over or transferred to any eligible retirement plan.  Unum will use the definition of eligible retirement plan as defined in Section 402 of the Internal Revenue Code including any future amendments which affect the definition. 6. The amount that you receive under Title 46, United States Code Section 688 (The Jones Act). With the exception of retirement payments, Unum will only subtract deductible sources of income which are payable as a result of the same disability. We will not reduce your payment by your Social Security retirement income if your disability begins after age 65 and you were already receiving Social Security retirement payments. Contribution.content: POLICYHOLDER  means the Employer to whom the policy is issued. PRE-EXISTING CONDITION  means a condition for which you received medical treatment, consultation, care or services including diagnostic measures, or took prescribed drugs or medicines for your condition during the given period of time as stated in the plan. RECURRENT DISABILITY  means a disability which is: -  caused by a worsening in your condition; and -  due to the same cause(s) as your prior disability for which Unum made a Long Term Disability payment. REGULAR CARE  means: -  you personally visit a physician as frequently as is medically required, according to generally accepted medical standards, to effectively manage and treat your disabling condition(s); and -  you are receiving the most appropriate treatment and care which conforms with generally accepted medical standards, for your disabling condition(s) by a physician whose specialty or experience is the most appropriate for your disabling condition(s), according to generally accepted medical standards. REGULAR OCCUPATION  means the occupation you are routinely performing when your disability begins.  Unum will look at your occupation as it is normally performed in the national economy, instead of how the work tasks are performed for a specific employer or at a specific location. For physicians, "regular occupation" means your specialty in the practice of medicine which you are routinely performing when your disability begins.  Unum will look at your occupation as it is normally performed in the national economy, instead of how the work tasks are performed for a specific employer or at a specific location. RETIREMENT PLAN  means a defined contribution plan or defined benefit plan.  These are plans which provide retirement benefits to employees and are not funded entirely by employee contributions. Retirement Plan includes but is not limited to any plan which is part of any federal, state, county, municipal or association retirement system. SALARY CONTINUATION OR ACCUMULATED SICK LEAVE  means continued payments to you by your Employer of all or part of your monthly earnings, after you become disabled as defined by the Policy.  This continued payment must be part of an established plan maintained by your Employer for the benefit of all employees covered under the Policy.  Salary continuation or accumulated sick leave does not include compensation paid to you by your Employer for work you actually perform after your disability begins.  Such compensation is considered disability earnings, and would be taken into account in calculating your monthly payment. SELF-REPORTED SYMPTOMS  means the manifestations of your condition which you tell your physician, that are not verifiable using tests, procedures or clinical examinations standardly accepted in the practice of medicine. Examples of self-reported symptoms include, but are not limited to headaches, pain, fatigue, stiffness, soreness, ringing in ears, dizziness, numbness and loss of energy.

Mental Illness Limitation.selected_text: Unum will not apply the mental illness limitation to dementia if it is a result of:
Mental Illness Limitation.content: The lifetime cumulative maximum benefit period for all disabilities due to  mental illness  and disabilities based primarily on  self-reported symptoms  is 24 months. Only 24 months of benefits will be paid for any combination of such disabilities even if the disabilities: -  are not continuous; and/or -  are not related. Unum will continue to send you payments beyond the 24 month period if you meet one or both of these conditions: 1.  If you are confined to a  hospital or institution  at the end of the 24 month period, Unum will continue to send you payments during your confinement. If you are still disabled when you are discharged, Unum will send you payments for a recovery period of up to 90 days. If you become reconfined at any time during the recovery period and remain confined for at least 14 days in a row, Unum will send payments during that additional confinement and for one additional recovery period up to 90 more days. 2.  In addition to Item 1, if, after the 24 month period for which you have received payments, you continue to be disabled and subsequently become confined to a hospital or institution for at least 14 days in a row, Unum will send payments during the length of the reconfinement. Unum will not pay beyond the limited pay period as indicated above, or the maximum period of payment, whichever occurs first. Unum will not apply the mental illness limitation to dementia if it is a result of: -  stroke; -  trauma; -  viral infection; -  Alzheimer's disease; or -  other conditions not listed which are not usually treated by a mental health provider or other qualified provider using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or other similar methods of treatment.
Mental Illness Limitation.narrative: According to Unum Policy 4702860.pdf, a mental illness limitation is imposed, restricting lifetime cumulative benefits for disabilities due to mental illness or self-reported symptoms to 24 months. Benefits will only be paid for up to 24 months regardless of whether the disabilities are continuous, unrelated, or both. Payments may extend beyond the initial 24-month period if the policyholder is confined to a hospital or institution at the end of the 24th month, with further payments during their confinement and for up to 90 days upon discharge if they remain disabled. If the policyholder becomes reconfined within the recovery period and remains so for at least 14 consecutive days, additional payments will be made for that additional confinement and another 90-day recovery period. The mental illness limitation does not apply to dementia caused by stroke, trauma, viral infection, Alzheimer's disease, or other conditions not typically treated by mental health providers using psychotherapy, psychotropic drugs, or similar methods.

Carrier.selected_text: CHANGES INSURANCE CARRIERS TO UNUM? (Continuity of Coverage)
Carrier.content: When Unum receives proof that you have died, we will pay your  eligible survivor  a lump sum benefit equal to 3 months of your gross disability payment if, on the date of your death: -  your disability had continued for 180 or more consecutive days; and -  you were receiving or were entitled to receive payments under the plan. If you have no eligible survivors, payment will be made to your estate, unless there is none.  In this case, no payment will be made. However, we will first apply the survivor benefit to any overpayment which may exist on your claim. You may receive your 3 month survivor benefit prior to your death if you have been diagnosed as terminally ill. We will pay you a lump sum amount equal to 3 months of your gross disability payment if: -  you have been diagnosed with a terminal illness or condition; -  your life expectancy has been reduced to less than 12 months; and -  you are receiving monthly payments. Your right to exercise this option and receive payment is subject to the following: -  you must make this election in writing to Unum; and -  your physician must certify in writing that you have a terminal illness or condition and your life expectancy has been reduced to less than 12 months. This benefit is available to you on a voluntary basis and will only be payable once. If you elect to receive this benefit prior to your death, no 3 month survivor benefit will be payable upon your death. WHAT IF YOU ARE NOT IN ACTIVE EMPLOYMENT WHEN YOUR EMPLOYER CHANGES INSURANCE CARRIERS TO UNUM? (Continuity of Coverage)
Carrier.narrative:
This Unum policy (4702860.pdf) outlines key provisions regarding survivor benefits and continuity of coverage. If your disability persisted for 180 days and you were receiving payments under the plan at the time of death, a lump sum equivalent to 3 months of gross disability payment will be paid to eligible survivors or the estate (if there are no survivors). Terminally ill policyholders can opt for an advance 3-month benefit. To qualify, you must provide written notice and your physician's certification of a terminal illness with less than a 12-month life expectancy.

In terms of continuity of coverage, Unum will provide coverage if you were not in active employment due to sickness or injury and were covered under the previous policy when the plan became effective, subject to payment of premiums. The payment will be limited to the amount that would have been paid by the prior carrier, with any remaining overpayment applied to your claim.

If your disability resulted from a pre-existing condition upon changing insurance carriers to Unum, Unum may send a payment if you were in active employment and insured under the plan on its effective date, while also being insured by the previous policy at the time of change. To receive a payment, you must satisfy either the Unum plan's pre-existing condition provision or that of the prior carrier's plan.

Finally, Unum has a Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program to help eligible policyholders return to work. Eligibility is determined at Unum's discretion, but you must be medically able to engage in a return-to-work program. Your claim file will be reviewed by a rehabilitation professional who will analyze medical and vocational information to determine an appropriate return-to-work program.

Your coverage is subject to payment of premium. Your payment will be limited to the amount that would have been paid by the prior carrier.  Unum will reduce your payment by any amount for which your prior carrier is liable.

Carrier.selected_text: 2.  the prior carrier's plan, if benefits would have been paid had that policy remained
Carrier.content: Unum may send a payment if your disability results from a pre-existing condition if, you were: -  in active employment and insured under the plan on its effective date; and -  insured by the prior policy at the time of change. In order to receive a payment you must satisfy the pre-existing condition provision under: 1.  the Unum plan; or 2.  the prior carrier's plan, if benefits would have been paid had that policy remained in force. If you do not satisfy Item 1 or 2 above, Unum will not make any payments. If you satisfy Item 1, we will determine your payments according to the Unum plan provisions. If you only satisfy Item 2, we will administer your claim according to the Unum plan provisions.  However, your payment will be the lesser of: a.  the monthly benefit that would have been payable under the terms of the prior plan if it had remained inforce; or b.  the monthly payment under the Unum plan. Your benefits will end on the earlier of the following dates: 1.  the end of the maximum benefit period under the plan; or 2.  the date benefits would have ended under the prior plan if it had remained in force. HOW CAN UNUM'S REHABILITATION AND RETURN TO WORK ASSISTANCE PROGRAM HELP YOU RETURN TO WORK? Unum has a vocational Rehabilitation and Return to Work Assistance program available to assist you in returning to work.  We will determine whether you are eligible for this program, at our sole discretion.  In order to be eligible for rehabilitation services and benefits, you must be medically able to engage in a return to work program. Your claim file will be reviewed by one of Unum's rehabilitation professionals to determine if a rehabilitation program might help you return to gainful employment. As your file is reviewed, medical and vocational information will be analyzed to determine an appropriate return to work program. We will make the final determination of your eligibility for participation in the program.

Worksite Modification.selected_text: A worksite modification might be what is needed to allow you to perform the material
Worksite Modification.content: A worksite modification might be what is needed to allow you to perform the material and substantial duties of your regular occupation with your Employer.  One of our designated professionals will assist you and your Employer to identify a modification we agree is likely to help you remain at work or return to work.  This agreement will be in writing and must be signed by you, your Employer and Unum. When this occurs, Unum will reimburse your Employer for the cost of the modification, up to the greater of: -  $1,000; or -  the equivalent of 2 months of your monthly benefit. This benefit is available to you on a one time only basis. HOW CAN UNUM'S SOCIAL SECURITY CLAIMANT ADVOCACY PROGRAM ASSIST YOU WITH OBTAINING SOCIAL SECURITY DISABILITY BENEFITS? In order to be eligible for assistance from Unum's Social Security claimant advocacy program, you must be receiving monthly payments from us.  Unum can provide expert advice regarding your claim and assist you with your application or appeal.
Worksite Modification.narrative:
According to Unum Policy 4702860.pdf, a worksite modification might be necessary for you to perform the essential duties of your job with your employer. A designated professional will aid both you and your employer in identifying an agreeable modification that could facilitate your continued employment or return to work. This agreement, signed by you, your employer, and Unum, enables Unum to reimburse your employer for the cost of the modification, up to $1,000 or twice the monthly benefit amount, on a one-time basis.

Additionally, Unum's Social Security Claimant Advocacy Program can provide expert advice and assistance with applications or appeals for Social Security Disability Benefits, but only if you are currently receiving monthly payments from Unum.
